info.game_comments:
1998 College Championship semifinal game 3.
From Zellerbach Auditorium at the University of California-Berkeley.

(1, 1).clue: "And the Lord God took the man, and put him into" this place "to dress it and keep it"

(2, 1).clue: It's the building where you'll find the head (of the 16th president) seen here

(3, 1).clue: In this game, the soda container stopped rotating & faces me... so kiss me already!

(4, 1).clue: Farsi is the official language of this Islamic republic

(5, 1).clue: She's the first woman to hold the post of Secretary of State

(1, 2).clue: He prayed to God for strength that "I may be at once avenged...for my two eyes"

(2, 2).clue: From Laos the statue seen here is a reclining version of this founder of a religion

(3, 2).clue: Careful!  Don't make the man's nose buzz while removing his funny bone in this game

(4, 2).clue: Scholars say the oldest form of this language can be found in the fifth chapter of Judges

(5, 2).clue: In 1992 this former British prime minister was made a baroness

(1, 3).clue: "And the glory of the Lord abode upon" this mountain, "and the cloud covered it six days"

(2, 3).clue: The name of these grotesque figures like this one seen here comes from an old word for "throat"

(3, 3).clue: An insignificant quest, or a game where you earn wedges in 6 categories

(4, 3).clue: Although there are many Berber dialects in Algeria, this is the official language

(5, 3).clue: India's national peace prize is named for this leader who was slain in 1984

(6, 3).clue: Instruct college kids on the art of oration

(1, 4).clue: He told King Darius, "My god hath sent his angel, and hath shut the lions' mouths"

(2, 4).clue: This country owns the island (Easter Island) where you'll find the guy seen here

(3, 4).clue: Calling all armchair Napoleons, it's the "Game of World Conquest"

(4, 4).clue: Galician, spoken in northwest Spain, is a dialect of the language spoken in this other Iberian country

(5, 4).clue: Her long work with chimps taught her "There is no sharp line dividing human from nonhuman"

(6, 4).clue: A casaba or cantaloupe in serious trouble with the law

(1, 5).clue: He cursed his grandson Canaan, saying, "A servant of servants shall he be unto his brethren"

(2, 5).clue: You'll find the statue ("David") seen here in this Italian city

(3, 5).clue: You go from career start or college start to Countryside Acres or Millionaire Estates in this game

(4, 5).clue: Chalti-Bhasa is the spoken form of this official language of Bangladesh

(5, 5).clue: This South African author & winner of a 1991 Nobel Prize once taught writing at Harvard

(6, 5).clue: A disease that breaks out in the Netherlands' seat of government

(1, 1).clue: Then & now president of Russia, in 1991 he saved Gorbachev's borscht after a coup attempt

(2, 1).clue: "The Memoirs of a Billiard-Marker" is a short story by this author of the very long "War and Peace"

(3, 1).clue: As this film's title character, Adam Sandler serenades a pair of newlyweds with the song "Love Stinks"

(4, 1).clue: From the Greek for "leave out", this solar event should never be viewed directly; use a pinhole projector

(5, 1).clue: Seen here, it's the tomb of Mumtaz

(6, 1).clue: "Tu" is the singular & familiar form of "you"; this is the plural & polite form

(1, 2).clue: Seen here, he ruled the USSR for over a third of its history

(2, 2).clue: Yes, dear, it's Wendy's last name in "Peter Pan"

(3, 2).clue: A Three Stooges short, seen here, featured an early film appearance by this comedienne

(4, 2).clue: Adidas products for this sport include World Cup cleats & the official ball for the 1998 World Cup

(5, 2).clue: You can usually get a "good deal" on this New York City bridge seen here

(6, 2).clue: Masculine & feminine are the 2 types of this, an English word that often takes the place of "sex"

(1, 3).clue: One of the USSR's 4 original republics, it was the site of the 1986 Chernobyl disaster

(2, 3).clue: This lord was England's poet laureate when he wrote "The Charge of the Light Brigade" in 1854

(3, 3).clue: Nick Nolte's son Brawley played Mel Gibson's kidnapped son in this 1996 film

(4, 3).clue: Mike D, Ad-Rock & MCA of this rap group hosted 1996's Tibetan Freedom Concert in San Francisco

(5, 3).clue: The London traffic junction & meeting place seen here

(6, 3).clue: Part of speech represented in the last word of the phrase "L'etat c'est moi"

(1, 4).clue: The Soviets kept their "Finn"gers crossed to sign a 1975 human rights accord in this city

(2, 4).clue: The title of this John Dos Passos trilogy has only 3 letters

(3, 4).clue: Helen Hunt made her Broadway debut in 1989 as Emily in a revival of this Thornton Wilder play

(4, 4).clue: American Airlines held an online contest giving away this Scott Adams hero's frequent flyer miles

(5, 4).clue: It's the "queen" of African waterfall royalty seen here

(6, 4).clue: The purity of the language is guarded by this group with just 40 members

(1, 5).clue: 1980s reforms included perestroika, "restructuring", & this Russian word for "openness"

(2, 5).clue: This "Heidi" author called her books "Stories for children and for those who love children"

(3, 5).clue: She's also the voice of Marge Simpson's sisters, Patty & Selma; they sound a lot like Marge

(4, 5).clue: Wild Wing is the mascot of this NHL team

(6, 5).clue: More dietary fiber might help "aller" & "devoir" as they are this kind of verb

(0, 0).clue: Alphabetically, he's the last individual member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
